    IT’S TIME TO IMPACT

    1 minute read

    On this page

    “Every Western institution was unprepared for the coronavirus pandemic, despite many prior warnings. This monumental failure of institutional effectiveness will reverberate for the rest of the decade…But the other part of the problem is what we didn’t do in advance, and what we’re failing to do now. And that is a failure of action, and specifically our widespread inability to build.” - IT’S TIME TO BUILD (April 2020)

    It’s November 6th, 2020. Since the start of the pandemic, we’ve seen the acceleration of technological adaption, and it’s been fantastic, from a investor perspective. However, there had been consequential adoption in misinformation, strategy, and investments.

    However, I would say that now we should focus on the following:

    • Investing in ourselves, is investing in others
    • Business Personafication & Identity
    • Good Trouble

    Vanity metrics are statistics that aspire to a business goal, meanwhile look hypothetically good. However, they only aspire, but never achieve to such goal. Actionable metrics are specific tasks that are either incrementally or reach your business goal.

    At the beginning of the COVID-19 outbreak, technologists and other thinkers envisoned a better future, through building processes for a better future. However, we must consider that maybe we had the pieces all along. However, are we making an impact?

    • Metrics about Economy

    • Focus on net-good deployment
    • Social Strife

      GoodTrouble

    • Example of clubhouse situations

    • Example of “It is what it is” It’s Time for Impact.

    The following was an important part to the article, but I would like to change something, seen highlighted:

    “Every step of the way, to everyone around us, we should be asking the question, what are you impacting? What are you impacting directly, or helping other people to impact, or teaching other people to impact, or taking care of people who are impacting? If the work you’re doing isn’t either leading to something being built or taking care of people directly, we’ve failed you, and we need to get you into a position, an occupation, a career where you can contribute to impacting. There are always outstanding people in even the most broken systems — we need to get all the talent we can on the biggest problems we have, and on building the answers to those problems.”

    Tags: Coding

    Updated: October 6, 2020
